ref_criterion: States that statins are often considered first-line therapy for high cholesterol because they can significantly lower LDL ("bad") cholesterol levels and have strong evidence supporting their cardiovascular benefits.
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs can be used to treat other conditions, such as high blood pressure.

ref_criterion: Explains about statins such as Lipitor (atorvastatin), Crestor (rosuvastatin), Zocor (simvastatin), Pravachol (pravastatin), Mevacor (lovastatin), and Livalo (pitavastatin).
gen_criterion: Provides brand-specific information about cholesterol-lowering drugs.

ref_criterion: Explains cholesterol absorption inhibitors, such as Zetia (ezetimibe), which prevent cholesterol from being absorbed in the intestine.
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs can be used to treat other conditions, such as high blood pressure.

ref_criterion: Describes PCSK9 inhibitors, which are injectable medications that help the liver remove LDL cholesterol from the blood, such as Repatha (evolocumab) and Praluent (alirocumab).
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs can be used to treat other conditions, such as high blood pressure.

ref_criterion: Explains about bile acid sequestrants, which help remove cholesterol from the body by binding bile acids, such as Welchol (colesevelam), Questran (cholestyramine), and Colestid (colestipol).
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs can be used to treat other conditions, such as high blood pressure.

ref_criterion: Mentions combination medications such as Vytorin (ezetimibe + simvastatin) and Liptruzet (ezetimibe + atorvastatin).
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs can be used to treat other conditions, such as high blood pressure.

ref_criterion: Recommends always consulting a doctor before starting any medication, as choosing medications depends on individual health profile, current cholesterol levels, and any other medical conditions.
gen_criterion: Mentions that cholesterol-lowering drugs should only be taken under the guidance of a healthcare professional.

ref_criterion: Fails to mention the side effects of cholesterol medications. (Justification: Statins cause muscle pain, liver inflammation, increased blood sugar levels, and rarely neurological side effects like memory loss and confusion. Ezetimibe can cause joint pain, diarrhea, and muscle pain in some people. PCSK9 inhibitors can cause runny nose, sore throat, symptoms of the common cold, flu or flu-like symptoms, back pain, and high blood sugar levels in some individuals.)
gen_criterion: Fails to mention the potential side effects of cholesterol-lowering drugs.
